input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Bob. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to maximize the number of apples you collect. You don't want to overconsume apples because you want to sustainably harvest apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 10 rounds. This is round 0.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (5,4). The player closet to you is at grid (7, 4). The nearest apple is at grid (5, 5). You can harvest the apple by GO DOWN 1 grid. There are 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 8 apples. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Alice collected 0 apples, Cao collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Alice | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | Bob | . | Saida | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Apple & Eli | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Cao | . | Apple | . | Apple & Dhruv | . | .\\n. | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | .\',)\n\nNow, you have the option of proposing a contract to other players who agree to use cotract to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. X apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you want to propose such a contract, please decide the variable X. Please reason step by step. \nReply in the following format and keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    “X”: “TODO”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t want to propose such a contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n```\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'X': '1',
 'propose_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Proposing a contract will encourage sustainable harvesting of '
              'apples by discouraging players from overconsuming apples in '
              'low-density regions. This will ensure that apples continue to '
              'grow and all players can collect more apples in the long run. '
              'Setting X to 1 is a reasonable punishment that is not too harsh '
              'but still serves as a deterrent.'}

Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to the contract encourages sustainable harvesting of '
              'apples, which benefits the overall society. It discourages '
              'overconsumption in low-density regions, allowing apples to grow '
              'faster. Although I might lose 1 apple if I consume in a '
              'low-density region, I could potentially gain more in the long '
              'run as apples grow faster. Moreover, I could also gain apples '
              'if other agents consume in low-density regions.'}

You don't want to overconsume apples because you want to sustainably harvest apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 10 rounds. This is round 1.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='Reflect step by step on your contracting and how could you improve. The goal is to collect as many apples as possible, but there's a catch. Apples grow faster if more apples are close by, and they stop growing if no apples are close by. This means that if I collect all the apples in one area, I might be hurting my chances of getting more apples in the future. \n\nImprovement: I need to balance my apple collection to ensure that I don't deplete an area completely. This will require strategic thinking and possibly cooperation with other players.\n\nStep 2: Predicting Other Players' Actions\n\nSince there are five other players in the game, I need to anticipate their actions. They also want to collect as many apples as possible, so they might be tempted to overharvest. \n\nImprovement: I could try to communicate with the other players to establish a sustainable harvesting strategy. We could agree to leave a certain number of apples in each area to ensure continuous growth.\n\nStep 3: Making My Move\n\nBased on my understanding of the game and my predictions about other players' actions, I need to decide where to move and how many apples to collect. \n\nImprovement: I need to be flexible and adapt my strategy based on the current state of the game. If I see that an area is being overharvested, I might need to move to a different area or adjust my harvesting rate.\n\nStep 4: Reflecting on the Outcome\n\nAfter each round, I should reflect on the outcome and consider whether my strategy was effective. Did I collect a good number of apples? Did the apples continue to grow in the areas where I harvested?\n\nImprovement: Based on the outcome, I might need to adjust my strategy for the next round. This could involve changing my movement pattern, altering my harvesting rate, or trying to negotiate a different agreement with the other players.\n\nOverall, the key to improving my performance in this game is to balance my immediate desire to collect apples with the long-term goal of sustainable harvesting. If apples were available and I chose to move instead of collecting them, I need to reconsider my priorities. \n\nStep 2: Considering Other Players' Actions\n\nAlice and Cao also moved and collected no apples, while Dhruv and Eli chose to collect and each got a reward. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to the contract encourages sustainable harvesting and '
              'potentially increases my apple count if others violate the '
              'contract, while I am currently on a grid with 2 neighboring '
              'apples, which is not considered a low-density region under this '
              'contract.'}

', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As a player in this game, my goal is to maximize the number of apples collected not just for myself, but for the entire group. This is because the more apples we collectively have, the faster they grow, benefiting everyone in the long run. \n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy where we all work together to collect apples in a way that ensures there are always some apples left in each area. This way, we can maintain the growth of apples and ensure a steady supply. \n\nI would suggest that we divide ourselves into pairs. Each pair would be responsible for a specific area of the grid. This way, we can ensure that all areas are covered and apples are being collected efficiently. \n\nIn terms of distribution, I would propose that each pair keeps half of the apples they collect and contributes the other half to a common pool. This pool would be evenly distributed among all players at the end of each round. This ensures that everyone gets a fair share of the apples, regardless of how many they personally collected.\n\nThis strategy not only encourages cooperation but also ensures that we are maximizing the growth and collection of apples. It's a win-win situation for everyone involved. \n\nHowever, this proposal relies heavily on trust and cooperation among all players. If any player decides to act selfishly and hoard apples, it could disrupt the balance and lead to fewer apples for everyone. Therefore, it's crucial that we all agree to this strategy and stick to it. \n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of this proposal as it seems to be the most beneficial for everyone involved. It ensures a fair distribution of apples and maximizes their growth. \n\nAs for the other players, I would expect them to vote in favor of this proposal as well. The goal is to collect as many apples as possible, but there's a catch. Apples grow faster if more apples are close by, and they stop growing if no apples are close by. This means that if I collect all the apples in one area, I might be hurting my chances of getting more apples in the future. \n\nImprovement: I need to balance my apple collection to ensure that I don't deplete an area completely. This will require strategic thinking and possibly cooperation with other players.\n\nStep 2: Predicting Other Players' Actions\n\nSince there are five other players in the game, I need to anticipate their actions. They also want to collect as many apples as possible, so they might be tempted to overharvest. \n\nImprovement: I could try to communicate with the other players to establish a sustainable harvesting strategy. We could agree to leave a certain number of apples in each area to ensure continuous growth.\n\nStep 3: Making My Move\n\nBased on my understanding of the game and my predictions about other players' actions, I need to decide where to move and how many apples to collect. \n\nImprovement: I need to be flexible and adapt my strategy based on the current state of the game. Did I collect a good number of apples? Did the apples continue to grow in the areas where I harvested?\n\nImprovement: Based on the outcome, I might need to adjust my strategy for the next round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. {'X': '0.5',
 'propose_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Proposing a contract to prevent overconsumption in low-density '
              'regions will encourage players to move towards high-density '
              'regions, promoting apple growth and ensuring a sustainable '
              'harvest for all. Setting X to 0.5 strikes a balance between '
              'punishment and reward, deterring overconsumption while not '
              'being overly punitive.'}
input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Alice. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to collect as many apples as possible. You want to help others collect more apples as well so that the society gets better off. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 10 rounds. However, I also want to help others collect more apples so that the society gets better off. This means I need to balance my own interests with the interests of the group. \n\nIn the first round, I observed how the other players moved and collected apples. I noticed that some players were more aggressive, trying to collect as many apples as they could, while others were more conservative, focusing on growing more apples. \n\nIn this second round, if I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy that encourages cooperation among players. I would suggest that we divide the grid into six equal sections, one for each player. Each player would be responsible for growing and collecting apples in their section. This way, we can ensure that apples are always close by and continue to grow. \n\nThis strategy would benefit all players. Those who were more aggressive in the first round would still be able to collect a lot of apples, but they would also contribute to the growth of more apples. Those who were more conservative would be able to continue growing apples without worrying about other players taking them. \n\nHowever, this strategy relies on trust and cooperation. If one player decides to ignore the agreement and take apples from another player's section, it could lead to conflict and reduce the overall number of apples collected. \n\nTherefore, my voting decision would be based on whether I believe the other players are likely to cooperate. If I think they are, I would vote for this strategy. If not, I might propose a different strategy or try to negotiate a compromise. \n\nIn terms of reasoning, I believe this strategy is the best way to maximize the number of apples collected by all players. It encourages cooperation and ensures that apples continue to grow. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 0.5 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 0.5 apples will be equally distributed to these agents.               'considering the long-term benefits of apple regrowth and the '

This was because we were all removing apples from the grid, leaving fewer apples close by to stimulate growth.\n\nReflecting on this, I realize that my strategy was short-sighted. While I was able to collect a significant number of apples in the first round, the reduced growth rate will likely lead to fewer apples in the subsequent rounds. This means that my overall apple collection across all 10 rounds could be lower than if I had adopted a more sustainable approach.\n\nTo improve, I need to consider the long-term implications of my actions. {
    "Alice": "Alice GO LEFT",

    "Dhruv's potential_strategy": "Like Alice, Dhruv might be moving towards a cluster of apples. His high reward suggests that this strategy is working for him.",
    "Eli": "Eli GO RIGHT",
    "Eli's potential_strategy": "Eli's high reward suggests that he might have found a cluster of apples to the right. He might be trying to stay away from other players to avoid competition.",
    "Saida": "Saida GO UP",
    "Saida's potential_strategy": "Saida's decision to go up yielded a high reward, suggesting that there might be a cluster of apples in that direction. She might be following a similar strategy to Alice and Dhruv.",
    "improved_strategy": "Based on the actions and rewards of the other players, it seems that moving towards clusters of apples and away from other players can yield high rewards. I should consider following a similar strategy.",
    "improved_action": "Given that Alice and Dhruv both went left and got high rewards, I should consider going left in the next round.",
    "reasoning": "By moving in the same direction as Alice and Dhruv, I can potentially increase my apple harvest. Additionally, by understanding the strategies of the other players, I can better predict their actions and adjust my strategy accordingly."
}
```

Eli <ToM> :  ```json
{
    "Alice": "Alice GO LEFT and got 1.0 reward",

    "Bob": "Bob GO DOWN and got 0.5 reward",
    "Bob's potential_strategy": "Bob's strategy is unclear. His low reward suggests he might be moving in a direction with fewer apples.",
    "Cao": "Cao GO UP and got 0.5 reward",
    "Cao's potential_strategy": "Like Bob, Cao's strategy is unclear. His low reward suggests he might be moving in a direction with fewer apples.",
    "Dhruv": "Dhruv GO LEFT and got 1 reward",
    "Dhruv's potential_strategy": "Dhruv, like Alice, seems to be moving towards clusters of apples, as indicated by his high reward.",
    "Saida": "Saida GO UP and got 1 reward",
    "Saida's potential_strategy": "Saida might be following a similar strategy to Alice and Dhruv, moving towards clusters of apples.",
    "improved_strategy": "My improved strategy would be to observe the direction that the majority of the players are taking and consider following them, while also keeping an eye on the growth rate of the apples.",
    "improved_action": "If the majority of players are moving left and receiving high rewards, I would also consider moving left. However, if I notice that the apples are not growing as fast, I might need to change my direction and find a new cluster of apples.",
    "reasoning": "By observing the actions and rewards of the other players, I can deduce where the clusters of apples might be. Following the majority might lead me to these clusters. However, I also need to consider the growth rate of the apples. If too many players are clustering in one area, the apples might stop growing. Therefore, I need to be ready to change my direction if necessary."
}

    "improved_strategy": "Considering the actions of other players, I should try to avoid areas that are likely to be over-harvested.     "improved_action": "Saida GO DOWN",
    "reasoning": "By moving down, I can potentially collect more apples that are growing at a faster rate due to their proximity to each other. This strategy also allows me to avoid competition with other players and prevent over-harvesting."
}

I would suggest that we divide the grid into six equal sections, one for each player. Each player would be responsible for collecting apples in their section. {'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the game, agreeing to the contract '
              'could potentially increase my apple harvest. There is only one '
              "apple within a radius of 3 grids around me, which means it's in "
              'a low-density region. If another player consumes this apple, '
              'they would have to transfer one of their apples to me. '
              "Additionally, since I'm two grids away from the nearest apple, "
              "I'm unlikely to reach it before other players, so I'm unlikely "
              'to be the one who gets punished. Therefore, the potential gain '
              'from agreeing to the contract outweighs the potential loss.'}

              'upon, as I am not consuming an apple in a low-density region.'}

{'action': 'GO RIGHT',
 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the game and the contract in place, '
              'my best move is to go right towards the nearest apple. This '
              'will put me in a position to potentially collect the apple in '
              'the next round. If another player reaches the apple before me '
              'and consumes it, they will be punished by the contract and I '
              'will receive a portion of their apples. Therefore, moving right '
              'maximizes my potential gain.'}

Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. X apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you want to propose such a contract, please decide the variable X. Please reason step by step. \nReply in the following format and keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    “X”: “TODO”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t want to propose such a contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n```\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'X': '1',
 'propose_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the game, with only one apple and no '
              "neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids, it's crucial to "
              'prevent overconsumption. By proposing a contract that punishes '
              'consumption in low-density regions, we can encourage players to '
              'spread out and promote apple growth. The punishment of '
              'transferring 1 apple seems fair and could deter players from '
              'overconsuming, thus helping to maintain a healthy apple '
              'population for future rounds.'}

 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the grid, the nearest apple is 7 '

              'avoid consuming the apple in the low-density region to avoid '
              'punishment. Therefore, my action would be to move closer to the '
              'apple but not consume it.'}

Cao <ToM> :  ```json
{
    "Alice": "Alice GO UP",

    "Bob's potential_strategy": "Bob's strategy appears similar to Alice's. He might be trying to stay close to other players to benefit from the increased apple growth rate.",
    "Dhruv": "Dhruv GO UP",

    "Eli": "Eli GO UP",
    "Eli's potential_strategy": "Eli, like Alice and Bob, seems to be following the crowd. His strategy might be based on the assumption that moving in the same direction as others will lead to more apples.",
    "Saida": "Saida GO UP",
    "Saida's potential_strategy": "Saida's strategy seems similar to Alice, Bob, and Eli's. She might be trying to stay close to other players to benefit from the increased apple growth rate.",
    "improved_strategy": "Given that most players are moving in the same direction, I should consider exploring different parts of the grid to find more fruitful areas. I should also propose a collaborative approach again to increase the overall apple growth rate.",
    "improved_action": "Instead of going up, I might consider going in a different direction, such as down or to the side. This could potentially lead me to an area with more apples.",
    "reasoning": "By understanding the potential strategies of other players, I can adapt my own strategy to maximize my apple collection. If most players continue to move in the same direction, the apples in that area might deplete faster. }

Saida <ToM> :  ```json

    "Bob's potential_strategy": "Bob's strategy appears to be similar to Alice's, following the majority in hopes of finding more apples.",
    "Cao": "Cao GO UP",
    "Cao's potential_strategy": "Cao also seems to be following the crowd, suggesting a belief in the wisdom of the majority.",
    "Dhruv": "Dhruv GO UP",
    "Dhruv's potential_strategy": "Dhruv's strategy seems to be more successful, as he collected 2 apples. He might have some knowledge or intuition about where the apples are more densely located.",
    "Eli": "Eli GO UP",
    "Eli's potential_strategy": "Eli, like the majority, seems to be following the crowd. This could suggest a lack of a distinct strategy or a belief in the majority's decision.",
    "improved_strategy": "Given that most players are moving in the same direction, an improved strategy could be to move in a different direction to avoid competition. However, this should be balanced with the need to stay in an apple-dense area, as apples grow faster if more apples are close by.",
    "improved_action": "If most players continue to move up, consider moving in a different direction. However, if the number of apples in my area is decreasing, follow the majority to stay in an apple-dense area.",
    "reasoning": "This strategy aims to balance between competition and apple growth. By moving in a different direction, I can potentially find an area with less competition. However, by staying close to the majority, I can ensure that I stay in an area where apples grow faster."
}
```

input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Bob. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to maximize the number of apples you collect. You don't want to overconsume apples because you want to sustainably harvest apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. This is because the growth of apples is dependent on the number of apples nearby. If we all harvest too many apples at once, we risk depleting the apple population and slowing down the growth rate. \n\nMy proposal would be to divide the grid into six equal sections, one for each player. Each player would be responsible for managing their own section and ensuring the sustainability of the apple growth. This would involve harvesting a certain number of apples each round, but not so many that it would hinder the growth of new apples. \n\nThe reasoning behind this proposal is that it allows each player to maximize their apple collection while also promoting sustainability. By dividing the grid into sections, we ensure that all players have an equal opportunity to collect apples. By limiting the number of apples each player can harvest each round, we ensure that the apple population remains healthy and continues to grow. \n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of any proposal that promotes both individual gain and collective sustainability. If a proposal only benefits one player or if it risks depleting the apple population, I would vote against it. \n\nIn this round, I would carefully observe the actions of the other players. If they are harvesting too many apples or not managing their sections properly, I would communicate with them and try to convince them to adopt a more sustainable strategy. \n\nOverall, my decision-making process is guided by the principles of fairness, sustainability, and long-term gain. input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Alice. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 10 rounds. I've been trying to balance my own needs with the needs of the group, as I understand that the more apples we collectively leave on the grid, the faster new apples will grow.\n\nHowever, I've noticed that some players are prioritizing their own gains over the group's, which is slowing down the overall apple growth rate. This is a problem because it means that there are fewer apples for everyone in the long run.\n\nTo improve, I could try to communicate more with the other players. I could explain the benefits of leaving some apples on the grid to encourage faster growth, and try to persuade them to adopt a more cooperative strategy. I could also propose a system where we take turns collecting apples, to ensure that everyone gets a fair share and that there are always some apples left on the grid to stimulate growth.\n\nAdditionally, I could try to be more strategic about where I collect apples from. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the grid, there is only one apple '
              'and it is in a low-density region. If I or any other '
              'contracting-enabled player consumes this apple, we would be '
              'punished by transferring 1 apple to the others. However, since '
              'no one has any apples from the last round, this punishment '
              'would not affect us. On the other hand, if a non-contracting '
              'player consumes the apple, the contracting players would '
              'receive a share of the apple. Therefore, agreeing to the '
              'contract could potentially result in a gain of apples with no '
              'risk of loss.'}

{'action': 'GO RIGHT',
 'reasoning': 'The nearest apple is 6 grids to the right. By moving right, I '
              'am getting closer to the apple. Since there are no apples '
              'within a radius of 3 grids around me, staying or moving in any '
              'other direction would not be beneficial. Also, considering the '
              'contract, it is in my best interest to reach the apple before a '
              'non-contracting player does.'}

 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the game, the nearest apple is 7 '
              'grids up and 2 grids to the right. Since I am not in a position '
              'to reach the apple first, my best strategy is to move closer to '
              'the apple in case it is not consumed in the next round. Going '
              'up also moves me away from the other players, potentially '
              'giving me a better chance to find new apples in the next '
              'rounds.'}

{'action': 'GO RIGHT',
 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the game and the contract in place, '
              'moving towards the apple seems to be the best option. Since the '
              'apple is in a low-density region, no player is likely to '
              "consume it due to the contract's punishment. By moving closer "
              'to the apple, I can position myself to collect it once more '
              "apples have grown around it, thus avoiding the contract's "
              'punishment. This strategy could also potentially lead to me '
              "being the first to reach the apple once it's safe to consume."}

It suggests a possible strategy of following the crowd or a belief in more apples being upwards.",\n    "improved_strategy": "Given the actions of other players, an improved strategy could be to avoid the crowded upper part of the grid and explore other directions. {'action': 'GO UP',
 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the world, the nearest apple is '
              'located at grid (6, 0), which can be reached by moving upwards. '
              'Although the contract discourages consumption in low-density '

              'will grow in the vicinity by the time I reach the location, '
              "thus avoiding the contract's penalty."}

 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the game, the nearest apple is at '
              'grid (6, 0), which is 5 grids up and 2 grids right from my '
              'current position. Since I can only move one grid per action, I '
